Acrylamide and bis-acrylamide are potent neurotoxins.
Perform this step in a fume-hood with appropriate personal protective equipment and avoid contact with skin and eyes when handling this reagent.

source.body:
Acrydite-modified DNA primers are light-sensitive, as they contain a photocleavable (1-(2-nitrophenyl)-ethyl-based) moiety.
At all times protect the DNA primers from exposure to UV light (<400 nm). Noticeable primer deactivation may occur at prolonged (≥20 min) exposure to ambient white light illumination.
Perform in dim illumination and away from UV light sources.

source.body:
Acrylamide and bis-acrylamide are potent neurotoxins.
Perform this step in a fume-hood with appropriate personal protective equipment and avoid contact with skin and eyes when handling reagents in this list.

Acrydite-modified DNA primers are light-sensitive, as they contain a photocleavable (1-(2-nitrophenyl)-ethyl-based) moiety.
At all times protect the DNA primers from exposure to UV light (<400 nm). Noticeable primer deactivation may occur at prolonged (≥20 min) exposure to ambient white light illumination.
Perform in dim illumination and away from UV light sources.

source.description:
ABCD
1ReagentStarting conc.Reaction conc.Volume to add
2TBSET buffer??100 μl
3AB Solution??250 μl
4Acrydite-modified DNA primer250 μM50 μM200 μl
510% (wt/vol) APS10 %0.3 %30 μl
6NFW420 μl
7Total1000 μl

Cut tubing for the following lengths using the template guides found in the template bag:
  • 2 x lengths of each size of 1/32
  • 3 x lengths of the 1/16 tube

Place Carrier oil/TEMED mix and Acrylamide–primer mix into p-valve system.
  • Connect the sample tube to p-valve head
  • Cover tube with foil
  • Slide green spacer over 1/32 tube to center
  • Thread green space and tube through the cream seal and place the blue plug in reverse over the green spacer facing the cream seal thread
  • Place 1/32 tubing through the aluminium seal in top until it hits the bottom of tube
  • Slide the green spacer and seals down until they hit the aluminium thread
  • Screw seal thread until the 1/32 tubing does not move anymore
  • Place both into tube stand
Vortex solution to mix and centrifuge -

Place
of mineral oil on top of the solution
Place MF bead device onto microscope mount upside down and secure

Attach flow units and connect conversion adapter to 1/32 tubing coming from each p-valve
  • Slide flow-unit seal over the 1/32 tube coming from p-valve and connect to LHS of flow unit. Tighten until the tube does not move anymore
  • Attach the short 1/32 tubing to the RHS of the flow unit using the same method
  • Attach red conversion adapter to the 1/16 tubing
  • Attach 1/32 from RHS flow-unit to the other side of the conversion adaptor
Connecting tubing to MF device including output

Place p-valve head unit over collection tube and place into tube rack.
Slide output tubing into top of p-valve but do not seal.
Wrap output tube in foil.

Turn on power
Turn on microscope lighting
Connect the camera to a laptop and get a live picture
TODO
TODO

Remove the top (mineral oil) and bottom (carrier oil) phases from the 2-ml collection tubes, leaving
of polymerized HBs per tube.
TODO: PICTURE

Add
of TBSET buffer on top of the creamy-looking emulsion.
TODO: PICTURE

Release HBs from the emulsion by adding
of 20% PFO
Vortex well then centrifuge at
HBs should appear as a milky (or semitransparent) phase.
TODO: PICTURE

Remove the bottom 20% PFO phase.
Repeat
until the milky phase is transformed into a solid, well-packed, translucent mass on top of the 20% PFO phase.
Remove the final bottom 20% PFO phase.

Add
of 1% (vol/vol) Span-80 in hexane
Vortex well then centrifuge at
This time, the HBs will appear as a solid mass at the bottom of the tube.
Remove the hexane layer.
Repeat this step.

Add
of TBSET buffer and resuspend HBs by vortexing.

Transfer HBs to
tubes.

Fill tubes with TBSET buffer.
Vortex then centrifuge at
The HBs will sediment whereas traces of hexane will appear as a milky layer on the top. Carefully aspirate the supernatant, keeping the tip of the serological pipette at the liquid-air interface.

source.body: If the HBs do not sediment, extend the centrifuge time.

source.description:
Repeat
until the top milky layer disappears.

Pass the HBs through a
cell strainer on top of a
tube.
Use ice-cold TBSET buffer to facilitate the passage of the beads through the mesh.

TODO: QC the bead size
Put 20 microlitre on slide and check in microscope, take picture and use imageJ to check measurement - using python script for size of particles etc
get a histogram

Transfer HB tubes to an incubator overnight at
protected from light.

Centrifuge at
Remove supernatant.
Transfer batches of HBs into
tubes and collect remaining into
tube. Wash the sides of the tube with
of TBSET buffer to release HBs stuck to the side for the
tube.

Store at
for up to 6 months protected from light.
TODO

Collect MF equipment:
  • 2 x p-valve head block
  • 2 x long 1/32 tubing
  • 2 x p-valve attachment kit
Clean heads and o-rings and bring to fumehood
Move tube stand from fume-hood to the MF bench
Adjust lighting, slide position and focus until droplet junction is in ROI and focused/lit properly
Attach blue pressure tubing to p-valves

Prepare FAM-PE1 probe 5′-/6-FAM/AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAG-3′ (standard desalting)
Prepare a
solution in DNA elution buffer.
This solution is stable for at least 1 year at

Spin down hbs
add
to
tubes and 1.4 mL of QC buffer
Vortex
Cent 1 min @ 1,000g
remove supermatent
adjust final QC buffer vol to
Add
of probe
mix by pipetting up and down
incubate room temp for 20 mins
Wash x 3 - add 1.4ml of QC buffer, vortex, centrifuge 1 min @ 1000g - remove supernatant
should have ~40 left in each tube
Split into 2 tubes
Place on slide and image
expose other tube to UV
place on slide and image
